Award.AwardTitle: Polynomial inclusions: open problems and potential applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to study a new geometric concept, polynomial inclusions, and their applications. It was first discovered by Newton that an interior point in a hollow ellipsoid feels no gravitational force, and that for a filled ellipsoid the gravity inside is a quadratic function of the position. Polynomial inclusions are a generalization of ellipsoids in terms of Newtonian potential. An interior point in a hollow polynomial inclusion feels a gravitational force that is a polynomial of the position. Polynomial inclusions have proven to be useful for many modeling and design problems. Specifically, the following applications pertaining to polynomial inclusions will be investigated: (i) predictive models for design of synthetic complex materials, (ii) optimal structures for fusion reactors and minimum field concentration, and (iii) inverse source problem for medical and geological imaging. This research project will be integrated with educational and outreach activities such as one-to-one mentoring, educational module development, training graduate students, and fostering interdisciplinary collaborations.

The Newtonian potential induced by a polynomial inclusion of degree k is precisely a polynomial of degree k inside the body. The interest in polynomial inclusions arises from that partial differential equations admit closed-form simple solutions for polynomial inclusions as for ellipsoids. The following fundamental technical problems concerning polynomial inclusions will be addressed in the project: (i) proving the existence and uniqueness of polynomial inclusions, (ii) numerically computing polynomial inclusions, (iii) explicit parametrization of polynomial inclusions and (iv) employing polynomial inclusions to solve aforementioned engineering problems. The outcomes of this project may have an impact on the classic Hilbert's sixteenth problem as well as industrial problems ranging from structural engineering, fusion designs and to imaging. The project will also strengthen the connection between the Department of Mathematics and the Department of Mechanical Aerospace Engineering at Rutgers University by means of recruiting students of diverse backgrounds into the research team.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aimed to investigate a special type of geometric shapes, named as polynomial inclusions by the PI, for which the solutions to a type of differential equations can be expressed as polynomials of spatial coordinates. These geometric shapes are generalizations of familiar spherical and ellipsoidal shapes from two perspectives. (i) Polynomial inclusions give rise to specific distribution of interior field strength and direction. (ii) Polynomial inclusions are optimal shapes for multifunctional composites under certain loading conditions. The specific goals of the project include but are not limited to: (i) a fundamental understanding of the existence and uniqueness of polynomial inclusions, (ii) an analytical and/or numerical method for computing these special shapes corresponding to a given polynomial, and (iii) algebraic parametrizations for polynomial inclusions.

The project has fulfilled these goals by in-depth investigation of this topic and publications in archival journals.  The results of the project provided the necessary theoretical foundation and numerical toolset from which further applications and properties of polynomial inclusions can be developed and proved. The project established an existence theorem of polynomial inclusions from the general theory of variational inequality and provided a counterexample concerning the uniqueness of polynomial inclusions. The proposed research results have also been applied to solve a few optimal design problems in the material modeling and offer useful design principles for high-performance multifunctional composites.  

Nevertheless, there are still many unknown properties and unanswered questions about polynomial inclusions that are worthwhile to be further investigated. For instance, the PI could not find simple algebraic parametrizations for polynomial inclusions in parallel to spheres and ellipsoids being parametrized by quadratic functions.

The project brought broader impacts within and beyond the immediate subject areas via fundamental mathematical research on novel geometric shapes and applications of this concept in materials design. The project has initiated collaborations between mathematics, engineering, and material science communities, and educational activities for undergraduate research and teaching. New research topic and collaboration has outgrown from the project to advance the development of new materials and training of workforce in STEM.
